primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God enters a world of monstrous evil (Herod/Sin) to establish a reign that transcends human judgment and suffering, specifically through the suffering of Christ.

tekstueel_bewijs: God the Father did not turn away.
He comes to make his blessings known.
The Holy Family is wonderfully preserved by God.

object.identificatie: The rectification of suffering and the establishment of the 'Last Word' of love.
tekstueel_bewijs: the unconditional love of God in Jesus Christ will be the Last Word
agonies of the victims will some day be rectified

zender.identificatie: The God of the Prophets (Jeremiah/Rachel passage)
tekstueel_bewijs: What was said through the prophet Jeremiah is fulfilled

ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer identifies as the Receiver/Witness who must 'not look away'.

tekstueel_bewijs: the comfort Father Lucic offered from the Christian Gospels
putting Rachel’s lament at the heart of the Christmas story
helper.rol_van_god: God is the Subject who suffers alongside the victims.
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit as the power of 'tenacity' in the faithful.

tegenstander.identificatie: The Monsters (Herod, Tyrants, Child Abusers, Death)
tekstueel_bewijs: monsters who kill in the night
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: The opponent is not just a moral failing but a 'monstrous' force that causes 'unimaginable suffering' and challenges the very existence of faith.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The call for the believer to face the darkness and name the monsters rather than retreating into sentimentality.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Mature Christian/Hearer
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The human response (naming monsters) is only possible because God first 'did not turn away'.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.helper_subject_tegenstander: The Cross/Lament → God in Christ ← Herod/The Monsters

voorbeelden_god_subject: God the Father did not turn away.
Jesus teaches us that human judgments are not the last judgments.
He comes to make his blessings known.
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We must listen to this objection.
We can’t run away from the suffering of the world.
I took my mother to church.

voorbeelden: We must listen to this objection again and again.
We must keep Ivan Karamazov’s protest in our minds.
I just wanted to be here with all the others.
be aware of the deep and far-reaching claims
the power that humans exercise over one another is not the final power

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on the 'Final Power' of God which overrules the 'Pouvoir' of the monsters. It moves from the human 'Savoir' (naming the horror) to God's 'Pouvoir' (the Last Word).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: The sermon moves from ~S1 (Sentimentality) to S2 (The reality of the Monsters), then to ~S2 (Lament/Rachel), finally arriving at S1 (The Savior Reigns) through the Cross.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The tension is resolved not by removing the monsters, but by God entering the S2 position (The Cross) to validate ~S2 (Lament).
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: Extremely high; the sermon refuses to minimize the horror of child abuse or war.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While there are many 'we must' statements, they are calls to *witness* and *honesty* rather than calls to *self-salvation*. The ultimate agency of rescue and the 'Last Word' is strictly reserved for God in Christ.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: This is the time for looking at monsters and naming them.

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as Subject of the 'Last Word'
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: the unconditional love of God in Jesus Christ will be the Last Word.
monsters who kill in the night... paranoia of King Herod

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Biblical figures are not used as moral examples to follow, but as participants in a cosmic drama of suffering and preservation.
bijbelse_figuren_als_model: Rachel (as a figure of lament, not a moral model)
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon already provides a theocentric reading: Jesus is the refugee, God is the one who does not turn away.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief through the validation of suffering; a shift from sentimentalism to 'forged' hope.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is grounded in the incarnation's entry into the worst of human experience.

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The sermon perfectly integrates the 'Rachel' narrative with the contemporary 'Monster' narrative, leading both to the 'Last Word' of the Cross.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'Joy to the World' and the 'Slaughter of the Innocents'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: human judgments are not the last judgments... the power that humans exercise... is not the final power.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The Spirit is implied in the 'tenacity' of the faithful in Sarajevo.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Critical; sin is seen as 'monstrous' and 'brutal', not just a mistake.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon is a masterclass in avoiding moralism by intensifying the Opponent (Monsters) to a degree that only a Divine Subject (God) can overcome.

modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Maintain the current focus on God's Pouvoir.
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Link the 'naming' of monsters more explicitly to the Holy Spirit's gift of discernment.

tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The sermon already treats the opponent with maximum seriousness.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: Soteriology (God's Last Word) remains the foundation for the secondary program of Christian honesty.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A profound example of how to preach 'God as Subject' in the face of radical evil without falling into easy answers or moralistic 'to-do' lists.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the Berlioz/Dostoevsky allusions; semiotics reveals that these serve to define the 'Opponent' actant.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis would focus on the Matthew/Jeremiah link; semiotics shows how that link functions as a 'Helper' for the hearer's faith.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Greimas reveals that the sermon's power comes from the 'Subject-switch'—moving from the human inability to protect children to God's ultimate power to rectify.

volledige_subject_lijst: We (must listen, can't run away, continue to believe)
appendices.notities: The sermon uses Rutledge's own criteria effectively by making God the subject of the eschatological active verbs.
